text.year: By how many years can the benchmark settings' data vary from the focus setting's data?

disclaimer.para1: The designations employed and the presentation of the material in this toolkit do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of WHO concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers or boundaries. Dotted and dashed lines on maps represent approximate border lines for which there may not yet be full agreement.
disclaimer.para2: The international borders of the map provided reflect the current political and geographic status as of the date of publication (2021). However, the technical health information is based on data accurate with respect to the year selected. The disconnect in this arrangement should be noted but no implications regarding political or terminological status should be drawn from this arrangement as it is purely a function of technical and graphical limitations.

disclaimers.nodefault: There is no data for this combination of variables.
disclaimers.nomap: There is either no data for this combination of variables or there are no boundaries of subnational regions that match those in the data. Maps are not available for MICS and RHS data.

titles.comparesumm: [indicator_name]: setting average and within-setting inequality (according to [dimension]) in [number_settings] settings

warnings.available: Estimates are displayed when data are available for the selected combination of variables; if estimates are not shown, data are not available.
warnings.availablemap: Estimates are displayed when data for the selected combination of variables and boundaries of subnational regions that match those in the data are available; if estimates are not shown, either data or boundaries are not available. Maps are not available for MICS and RHS data.

text.graph: The graph will be downloaded as a png or jpg image or pdf. Titles and axis labels will be displayed according to your selections.
text.map: The graph will be downloaded as a png or jpg image or pdf. Titles will be displayed according to your selections.
text.data: The data will be downloaded as a text file with values separated by commas or tabs, according to your selection. These can be opened in a text editor or spreadsheet package.
text.heat1: Health Equity Assessment Toolkit (HEAT): Software for exploring and comparing health inequalities in countries. Built-in database edition. Version 4.0. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2021.
text.heat2: The disaggregated data used in this version were drawn from the WHO Health Equity Monitor database (2020 update) which may have been revised or updated since that time. The most recent version of that database is available on the WHO website (https://www.who.int/data/gho/health-equity/health-equity-monitor-database).
text.disclaimer1: The designations employed and the presentation of the material in this toolkit do not imply the expression of any opinion whatsoever on the part of WHO concerning the legal status of any country, territory, city or area or of its authorities, or concerning the delimitation of its frontiers or boundaries. Dotted and dashed lines on maps represent approximate border lines for which there may not yet be full agreement.
text.disclaimer2: The international borders of the map provided reflect the current political and geographic status as of the date of publication (2021). However, the technical health information is based on data accurate with respect to the year selected. The disconnect in this arrangement should be noted but no implications regarding political or terminological status should be drawn from this arrangement as it is purely a function of technical and graphical limitations.
text.heatplus1: Health Equity Assessment Toolkit Plus (HEAT Plus): Software for exploring and comparing health inequalities in countries. Upload database edition. Version 4.0. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2021.
text.heatplus2: WHO provides this toolkit without data, and all data added to, or resulting from, the toolkit are the sole responsibility of the user, not WHO.

citations.heat1: Suggested citation: Health Equity Assessment Toolkit (HEAT): Software for exploring and comparing health inequalities in countries. Built-in database edition. Version 4.0. Geneva: WHO, 2021.
citations.heatplus1: Suggested citation: Health Equity Assessment Toolkit Plus (HEAT Plus): Software for exploring and comparing health inequalities in countries. Upload database edition. Version 4.0. Geneva: WHO, 2021.
citations.heatplus2: WHO provides this toolkit without data, and all data added to, or resulting from, the toolkit are the sole responsibility of the user, not WHO.

paragraphs.heat1: This built-in database edition of the HEAT software uses data from the WHO Health Equity Monitor database (2020 update).
paragraphs.heat2: HEAT enables the interactive exploration and comparison of health inequalities in countries.
paragraphs.heat3c: in one country of interest to determine the latest situation of inequality and the change in inequality over time.
paragraphs.heat4: Health inequality data, including disaggregated data and summary measures, are visualized in a variety of interactive graphs, maps and tables.
paragraphs.heat5c: in one country of interest with the situation in other countries and do benchmarking.
paragraphs.heat6: Customized results can be exported and saved in different formats.
paragraphs.heat7: Measuring and monitoring health inequalities is crucial to identify differences in health between different population subgroups, providing important evidence for policies, programmes and practices that aim to tackle health inequities and achieve health for all.
paragraphs.heat8: The Health Equity Assessment Toolkit facilitates the analysis and reporting of health inequality data. Disaggregated data and summary measures are visualised in a variety of interactive ways. Customized results can be exported and used to inform priority-setting and policy-making.

paragraphs.heatplus3: Health inequality data, including disaggregated data and summary measures, are visualized in a variety of interactive graphs and tables.

paragraphs.heatplus6: Measuring and monitoring health inequalities is crucial to identify differences in health between different population subgroups, providing important evidence for policies, programmes and practices that aim to tackle health inequities and achieve health for all.
paragraphs.heatplus7: The Health Equity Assessment Toolkit Plus facilitates the analysis and reporting of health inequality data. Disaggregated data and summary measures are visualized in a variety of interactive ways. Customized results can be exported and used to inform priority-setting and policy-making.

labels.disclaimer: Datasets have to be in a specific format and stored as comma separated values (csv) or Microsoft Excel (xls or xlsx) files in order to be uploaded to HEAT Plus. The HEAT Plus template and validation tool helps you prepare your data according to the template and validate that your dataset has been formatted correctly. Please refer to the user manual for further information.

warnings.variables: The file does not have all the required variables
warnings.mandatory: One of the mandatory variables has missing values
warnings.notmandatory: There are missing values in the estimate variable. While not mandatory, if data for this variable are missing some calculations will not function in HEAT Plus.
warnings.characters: Not all character variables contain characters (text/string)
warnings.iso3: Not all ISO3 values are three characters
warnings.numbers: Variables that should be only numbers contain characters (text/string)
warnings.years: Not all years are four-digit numbers
warnings.integers: There are decimal numbers where integers are required
warnings.negatives: There are negative numbers where negative numbers are not allowed
warnings.positives: Variables that must be positive or missing are negative
warnings.binary: Variables that must be binary have non 1/0 values
warnings.orderedvars: There is a problem with the ordered variables
warnings.sequence: Subgroup order must be an increasing sequence of integers starting with 1 when ordered dimension = 1
warnings.settings: Setting and ISO3 are not consistent
warnings.abbreviations: Indicator abbreviation and name are not uniquely matched
warnings.ordereddims: There is inconsistency in ordered dimensions

labels.heatplus: Health Equity Assessment Toolkit Plus (HEAT Plus)

text.calculations: Difference and ratio measures are calculated for dimensions with 30 subgroups or more. If estimates are not available, then summary measures cannot be calculated.

indicators.mdbu: Mean difference from best performing subgroup (unweighted) (MDBU)
indicators.mdbw: Mean difference from best performing subgreoup (weighted) (MDBW)
indicators.asfr1: Adolescent fertility rate (births per 1000 women aged 15-19 years)
indicators.anc45: Antenatal care coverage - at least four visits (in the five years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.anc4: Antenatal care coverage - at least four visits (in the two or three years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.anc15: Antenatal care coverage - at least one visit (in the five years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.anc1: Antenatal care coverage - at least one visit (in the two or three years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.sba5: Births attended by skilled health personnel (in the five years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.sba: Births attended by skilled health personnel (in the two or three years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.csection5: Births by caesarean section (in the five years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.csection: Births by caesarean section (in the two or three years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.itnch: Children aged < 5 years sleeping under insecticide-treated nets (%)
indicators.ors: Children aged < 5 years with diarrhoea receiving oral rehydration salts (%)
indicators.ort: Children aged < 5 years with diarrhoea receiving oral rehydration therapy and continued feeding (%)
indicators.carep: Children aged < 5 years with pneumonia symptoms taken to a health facility (%)
indicators.vita: Children aged 6-59 months who received vitamin A supplementation (%)
indicators.cpmt: Contraceptive prevalence - use of modern and traditional methods (%)
indicators.cpmowho: Contraceptive prevalence - use of modern methods (%)
indicators.fps: Demand for family planning satisfied - use of modern and traditional methods (%)
indicators.fpsmowho: Demand for family planning satisfied - use of modern methods (%)
indicators.bfearly: Early initiation of breastfeeding (in the two years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.bfearly.1: Early initiation of breastfeeding (in the five years preceding the survey) (%)
indicators.imr: Infant mortality rate (deaths per 1000 live births)
indicators.nmr: Neonatal mortality rate (deaths per 1000 live births)
indicators.bmi30wm: Obesity prevalence in non-pregnant women aged 15-49 years, BMI >= 30 (%)
indicators.overweight: Overweight prevalence in children aged < 5 years (%)
indicators.itnwm: Pregnant women sleeping under insecticide-treated nets (%)
indicators.sevwasting: Severe wasting prevalence in children aged < 5 years (%)
indicators.stunting: Stunting prevalence in children aged < 5 years (%)
indicators.u5mr: Under-five mortality rate (deaths per 1000 live births)
indicators.underweight: Underweight prevalence in children aged < 5 years (%)
indicators.wasting: Wasting prevalence in children aged < 5 years (%)
